title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Continuing Education Activity
content: Parry Romberg syndrome (PRS) or progressive hemifacial atrophy is a progressive idiopathic disorder, presenting in early childhood, with a spontaneous halt and remission in the teenage years. Therefore, the management of cosmetic disfigurement, neurological, psychological, and ophthalmological manifestations poses a significant challenge. This activity outlines the clinical presentation, evaluation, and management of PRS and highlights the role of an interprofessional team in providing better care and rehabilitation of these patients.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Continuing Education Activity. Parry Romberg syndrome (PRS) or progressive hemifacial atrophy is a progressive idiopathic disorder, presenting in early childhood, with a spontaneous halt and remission in the teenage years. Therefore, the management of cosmetic disfigurement, neurological, psychological, and ophthalmological manifestations poses a significant challenge. This activity outlines the clinical presentation, evaluation, and management of PRS and highlights the role of an interprofessional team in providing better care and rehabilitation of these patients.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Continuing Education Activity
content: Objectives: Describe the clinical manifestations of Parry Romberg syndrome (PRS). Review the diagnostic approach and summarise the systemic treatment options for PRS. Explain the management guidelines for the ocular manifestations of PRS. Outline the modalities of cosmetic rehabilitation of the patients of PRS. Access free multiple choice questions on this topic.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Continuing Education Activity. Objectives: Describe the clinical manifestations of Parry Romberg syndrome (PRS). Review the diagnostic approach and summarise the systemic treatment options for PRS. Explain the management guidelines for the ocular manifestations of PRS. Outline the modalities of cosmetic rehabilitation of the patients of PRS. Access free multiple choice questions on this topic.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Introduction
content: Parry Romberg syndrome (PRS), also referred to as progressive hemifacial atrophy, progressive facial hemiatrophy, or idiopathic hemifacial atrophy, was first described by C Parry and M Romberg. [1] It is an idiopathic, gradually progressive craniofacial asymmetry, following the atrophy of subcutaneous tissue, muscles, osseous, and cartilaginous structures. It manifests in the first two decades in morphologically normal-born individuals. It commonly affects one or more dermatomes in the trigeminal nerve territory. It has an early onset of ophthalmic and neurological involvement and a variable maxillo-facial or cardiac involvement.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Introduction. Parry Romberg syndrome (PRS), also referred to as progressive hemifacial atrophy, progressive facial hemiatrophy, or idiopathic hemifacial atrophy, was first described by C Parry and M Romberg. [1] It is an idiopathic, gradually progressive craniofacial asymmetry, following the atrophy of subcutaneous tissue, muscles, osseous, and cartilaginous structures. It manifests in the first two decades in morphologically normal-born individuals. It commonly affects one or more dermatomes in the trigeminal nerve territory. It has an early onset of ophthalmic and neurological involvement and a variable maxillo-facial or cardiac involvement.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Etiology
content: The exact etiopathogenesis is still a topic of debate. The most commonly accepted theories are:
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Etiology. The exact etiopathogenesis is still a topic of debate. The most commonly accepted theories are:

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Etiology
content: Theory of "trophoneurosis": The earliest understanding was a dysfunction of the trophic fibers of the trigeminal and other peripheral nerves—the complaints of chronic facial pain and trigeminal neuralgia support this theory. Confocal microscopy shows a reduction in the corneal nerve endings, supplied by the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve, supporting this theory. [2]
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Etiology. Theory of "trophoneurosis": The earliest understanding was a dysfunction of the trophic fibers of the trigeminal and other peripheral nerves—the complaints of chronic facial pain and trigeminal neuralgia support this theory. Confocal microscopy shows a reduction in the corneal nerve endings, supplied by the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve, supporting this theory. [2]

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Etiology
content: Immune-mediated process : The widely accepted theory is PRS being an autoimmune disorder. [3] Overlap with linear morphea, a form of systemic sclerosis, has been commonly observed. [4] The presence of other autoimmune diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, ankylosing spondylitis, vitiligo, and thyroid disorders have been noted in rare cases. [5] The presence of anti-nuclear antibodies provides a definitive serological basis. [6] [7]
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Etiology. Immune-mediated process : The widely accepted theory is PRS being an autoimmune disorder. [3] Overlap with linear morphea, a form of systemic sclerosis, has been commonly observed. [4] The presence of other autoimmune diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, ankylosing spondylitis, vitiligo, and thyroid disorders have been noted in rare cases. [5] The presence of anti-nuclear antibodies provides a definitive serological basis. [6] [7]

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Etiology
content: Neuro-vasculitis theory: The histopathology of the cerebral lesions reveals a lymphocytic vasculitis similar to Rasmussen encephalitis. [8] Interstitial neurovasculitis involving the major vessels explains the aneurysms and other cerebrovascular malformations, seen occasionally in PRS cases. Similar lesions are described along the course of the trigeminal nerve. [9]
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Etiology. Neuro-vasculitis theory: The histopathology of the cerebral lesions reveals a lymphocytic vasculitis similar to Rasmussen encephalitis. [8] Interstitial neurovasculitis involving the major vessels explains the aneurysms and other cerebrovascular malformations, seen occasionally in PRS cases. Similar lesions are described along the course of the trigeminal nerve. [9]

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Etiology
content: Neural crest cell disorder: The presence of cerebral vascular malformations and aneurysms, along with soft tissue tumors, suggests a possible dysregulation of neural crest cell migration. [10]
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Etiology. Neural crest cell disorder: The presence of cerebral vascular malformations and aneurysms, along with soft tissue tumors, suggests a possible dysregulation of neural crest cell migration. [10]

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Etiology
content: Sympathetic dysfunction: The superior cervical sympathetic plexus inflammation or dysfunction causes ipsilateral facial atrophy, enophthalmos, and bone atrophy - similar to PRS. Ipsilateral sympathectomy shows a halt of the disease progression. [11] [12]
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Etiology. Sympathetic dysfunction: The superior cervical sympathetic plexus inflammation or dysfunction causes ipsilateral facial atrophy, enophthalmos, and bone atrophy - similar to PRS. Ipsilateral sympathectomy shows a halt of the disease progression. [11] [12]

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Etiology
content: Hereditary mechanism: Wartenberg described PRS as a heredo-degenerative disorder, with only a few familial cases noted to date. No specific inheritance pattern or gene has been isolated. [13]
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Etiology. Hereditary mechanism: Wartenberg described PRS as a heredo-degenerative disorder, with only a few familial cases noted to date. No specific inheritance pattern or gene has been isolated. [13]

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Etiology
content: Trauma-induced: Online surveys of PRS patients have established a debatable association of head injury in early childhood to the onset of symptoms. [14]
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Etiology. Trauma-induced: Online surveys of PRS patients have established a debatable association of head injury in early childhood to the onset of symptoms. [14]

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Etiology
content: Infectious causes: Preceding infections with Varicella zoster virus, Herpes simplex virus, and Borrelia burgorferi have been described as risk factors. [15] [16]
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Etiology. Infectious causes: Preceding infections with Varicella zoster virus, Herpes simplex virus, and Borrelia burgorferi have been described as risk factors. [15] [16]

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Epidemiology
content: The incidence of PRS varies from 0.3 to 2.5 cases per 100,000 population per year, with a male: female ratio of 1 to 3. [14] [17]
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Epidemiology. The incidence of PRS varies from 0.3 to 2.5 cases per 100,000 population per year, with a male: female ratio of 1 to 3. [14] [17]

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Epidemiology
content: The onset of PRS is in the first two decades of life, with a few cases in the elderly age group. [18] The average age of diagnosis is 13.2 years, with an earlier diagnosis in the male population. [19] The disease shows a progressive course, followed by a 'burn out' within 2 to 20 years and spontaneous remission. [3] Ophthalmic involvement occurs in up to 35% of cases. [20] Neurological symptoms manifest in 15 to 20% of cases. [14]
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Epidemiology. The onset of PRS is in the first two decades of life, with a few cases in the elderly age group. [18] The average age of diagnosis is 13.2 years, with an earlier diagnosis in the male population. [19] The disease shows a progressive course, followed by a 'burn out' within 2 to 20 years and spontaneous remission. [3] Ophthalmic involvement occurs in up to 35% of cases. [20] Neurological symptoms manifest in 15 to 20% of cases. [14]

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Pathophysiology
content: PRS is predominantly an autoimmune disorder with similarities to localized scleroderma or morphea.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Pathophysiology. PRS is predominantly an autoimmune disorder with similarities to localized scleroderma or morphea.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Pathophysiology
content: The closest mimic is linear scleroderma en coup de sabre (LSCS). [21] The major distinguishing feature is the absence of cicatricial alopecia and skin induration in PRS cases. In contrast, LSCS shows cutaneous sclerosis of the scalp, hyperpigmentation, and loss of scalp hair and eyebrows.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Pathophysiology. The closest mimic is linear scleroderma en coup de sabre (LSCS). [21] The major distinguishing feature is the absence of cicatricial alopecia and skin induration in PRS cases. In contrast, LSCS shows cutaneous sclerosis of the scalp, hyperpigmentation, and loss of scalp hair and eyebrows.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Histopathology
content: Skin biopsy shows near-complete dermal fat atrophy, minimal sclerosis, and reduced adnexal structures. The characteristic finding is a diffuse pattern of dermal infiltration with lymphocyte predominance and perivascular plasma cells. [21] Brain biopsy, though not routinely done for PRS, shows lymphocytic interstitial vasculitis.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Histopathology. Skin biopsy shows near-complete dermal fat atrophy, minimal sclerosis, and reduced adnexal structures. The characteristic finding is a diffuse pattern of dermal infiltration with lymphocyte predominance and perivascular plasma cells. [21] Brain biopsy, though not routinely done for PRS, shows lymphocytic interstitial vasculitis.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical
content: The clinical criteria, as proposed by Duymaz et al. favoring a diagnosis of PRS over scleroderma, are: [3] Unilateral facial atrophy Absent/minimal signs of prior inflammation or induration Skin atrophy with thin, soft skin and no sclerosis The clinical symptoms and features to look out for during history taking and physical examination are:
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical. The clinical criteria, as proposed by Duymaz et al. favoring a diagnosis of PRS over scleroderma, are: [3] Unilateral facial atrophy Absent/minimal signs of prior inflammation or induration Skin atrophy with thin, soft skin and no sclerosis The clinical symptoms and features to look out for during history taking and physical examination are:

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Facial
content: Facial atrophy: Progressive facial asymmetry due to atrophy of the subcutaneous fat, muscles, and underlying bones - the most common clinical finding Pigmentation: Hypo- or hyperpigmented lesions over the face and ipsilateral neck Alopecia: Involving the eyebrow and the eyelashes
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Facial. Facial atrophy: Progressive facial asymmetry due to atrophy of the subcutaneous fat, muscles, and underlying bones - the most common clinical finding Pigmentation: Hypo- or hyperpigmented lesions over the face and ipsilateral neck Alopecia: Involving the eyebrow and the eyelashes

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic
content: Enophthalmos: Progressive enophthalmos secondary to atrophy of retrobulbar fat and the alterations in orbital anatomy due to bone atrophy
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic. Enophthalmos: Progressive enophthalmos secondary to atrophy of retrobulbar fat and the alterations in orbital anatomy due to bone atrophy

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic
content: Eye-lid alterations: Pseudoptosis secondary to enophthalmos, lid retraction, lagophthalmos, eyelid atrophy, and late-onset eyelid pseudo-coloboma. [22]
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic. Eye-lid alterations: Pseudoptosis secondary to enophthalmos, lid retraction, lagophthalmos, eyelid atrophy, and late-onset eyelid pseudo-coloboma. [22]

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic
content: Orbital tumors: Orbital neurinoma - an incidental finding on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) [23]
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic. Orbital tumors: Orbital neurinoma - an incidental finding on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) [23]

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic
content: Extraocular muscle (EOM) changes: Thinning or fibrosis of EOM, sudden onset horizontal or vertical strabismus, nystagmus, and diplopia.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic. Extraocular muscle (EOM) changes: Thinning or fibrosis of EOM, sudden onset horizontal or vertical strabismus, nystagmus, and diplopia.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic
content: Conjunctival pigmentation: Abnormal pigmentation of the palpebral conjunctiva
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic. Conjunctival pigmentation: Abnormal pigmentation of the palpebral conjunctiva

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic
content: Scleral finding: Spontaneous scleral melt [24]
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic. Scleral finding: Spontaneous scleral melt [24]

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic
content: Corneal manifestations: Reduced corneal sensations, reduced stromal nerve fibers on confocal microscopy, exposure to keratopathy with secondary infective keratitis, keratitc precipitates, primary endothelial failure, stromal edema, band-shaped keratopathy, and flour-like deposits in the corneal stroma. [25]
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic. Corneal manifestations: Reduced corneal sensations, reduced stromal nerve fibers on confocal microscopy, exposure to keratopathy with secondary infective keratitis, keratitc precipitates, primary endothelial failure, stromal edema, band-shaped keratopathy, and flour-like deposits in the corneal stroma. [25]

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic
content: Uveal changes: Acute uveitis with iritis, iridocyclitis, vitritis, panuveitis, iris atrophy, iris crystalline deposits, and Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis. [26]
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic. Uveal changes: Acute uveitis with iritis, iridocyclitis, vitritis, panuveitis, iris atrophy, iris crystalline deposits, and Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis. [26]

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic
content: Lens findings: Cataract and lenticular dislocation
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic. Lens findings: Cataract and lenticular dislocation

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic
content: Intra-ocular pressure (IOP) alterations: Rise of IOP with acute trabeculitis or end-stage neovascular glaucoma, and ocular hypotony with iridocyclitis, ciliary body hypotrophy, or atrophy
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic. Intra-ocular pressure (IOP) alterations: Rise of IOP with acute trabeculitis or end-stage neovascular glaucoma, and ocular hypotony with iridocyclitis, ciliary body hypotrophy, or atrophy

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic
content: Retinal findings: Retinal vasculitis, neuroretinitis, telangiectasia, pigment epithelial changes, retinal folds, exudative retinal detachment (RD), Coats disease, central retinal artery occlusion, chorioretinal atrophy, and retinitis pigmentosa like changes
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic. Retinal findings: Retinal vasculitis, neuroretinitis, telangiectasia, pigment epithelial changes, retinal folds, exudative retinal detachment (RD), Coats disease, central retinal artery occlusion, chorioretinal atrophy, and retinitis pigmentosa like changes

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic
content: Involutional stage: Multiple vitreoretinal or glaucoma filtration surgeries predispose the globe to involutional changes
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Ophthalmic. Involutional stage: Multiple vitreoretinal or glaucoma filtration surgeries predispose the globe to involutional changes

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Neuro-ophthalmological
content: Optic nerve involvement: Optic neuropathy and papillitis Cranial nerve palsy: Oculomotor and trochlear nerve palsy, with restrictive strabismus Anisocoria : Horner syndrome and tonic pupil - due to autonomic disturbances
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Neuro-ophthalmological. Optic nerve involvement: Optic neuropathy and papillitis Cranial nerve palsy: Oculomotor and trochlear nerve palsy, with restrictive strabismus Anisocoria : Horner syndrome and tonic pupil - due to autonomic disturbances

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Neurologic
content: Epilepsy: Focal, generalized seizures or status epilepticus Pain: Headche, trigeminal neuralgia, and facial pain Cerebro-vascular accidents: Ischemic stroke, cerebral hemorrhage, microinfarcts, microhemorrhages, and subsequent cerebral atrophy Vascular malformations: Aneurysms, cavernoma, hypoplastic or stenotic vessels Movement disorders: Muscle spasms, synkinesia, pyramidal symptoms, dystonia, torticollis, and gait disturbances Speech abnormalities: Aphasia and dysarthria Limb abnormalities: Limb weakness, pain, or atrophy in rare cases [14] Neuropsychiatric manifestations: Cognitive disturbances, hallucinations, and psychiatric disorders
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Neurologic. Epilepsy: Focal, generalized seizures or status epilepticus Pain: Headche, trigeminal neuralgia, and facial pain Cerebro-vascular accidents: Ischemic stroke, cerebral hemorrhage, microinfarcts, microhemorrhages, and subsequent cerebral atrophy Vascular malformations: Aneurysms, cavernoma, hypoplastic or stenotic vessels Movement disorders: Muscle spasms, synkinesia, pyramidal symptoms, dystonia, torticollis, and gait disturbances Speech abnormalities: Aphasia and dysarthria Limb abnormalities: Limb weakness, pain, or atrophy in rare cases [14] Neuropsychiatric manifestations: Cognitive disturbances, hallucinations, and psychiatric disorders

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Maxillofacial
content: Bony changes: Hypoplasia of the maxilla, zygomatic bone, mandible, temporal, and rarely frontal bones Oral manifestations: Unilateral tongue atrophy, gingival atrophy, atrophy of hard palate, and abnormal development of the teeth
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Maxillofacial. Bony changes: Hypoplasia of the maxilla, zygomatic bone, mandible, temporal, and rarely frontal bones Oral manifestations: Unilateral tongue atrophy, gingival atrophy, atrophy of hard palate, and abnormal development of the teeth

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Cardiac
content: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and rheumatologic heart disease
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Cardiac. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and rheumatologic heart disease

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Endocrine
content: Hashimoto thyroiditis and metabolic disorder.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- History and Physical -- Endocrine. Hashimoto thyroiditis and metabolic disorder.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Evaluation
content: PRS is primarily a clinical diagnosis. Various investigation modalities can be employed to rule out any overlap with similarly presenting syndromes.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Evaluation. PRS is primarily a clinical diagnosis. Various investigation modalities can be employed to rule out any overlap with similarly presenting syndromes.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Evaluation -- Ocular Evaluation
content: Best-corrected visual acuity, refraction, and pupillary reaction assessment General examination for symmetry of the face, head posture, extra-ocular muscle movements, and strabismus workup Orbit examination, evaluation of lid abnormalities, and ptosis workup Meticulous slit-lamp examination IOP measurement by Goldmann applanation tonometry Detailed fundus examination Orbital ultrasound: In cases with media opacity due to vitritis, cataract, or corneal opacity, this modality helps diagnose the associated posterior segment pathology. Ultrasound biomicroscopy is used to look for ciliary body changes. [15] Orbital imaging: Orbital computed tomography (CT) scan is used to evaluate the changes in bony orbit.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Evaluation -- Ocular Evaluation. Best-corrected visual acuity, refraction, and pupillary reaction assessment General examination for symmetry of the face, head posture, extra-ocular muscle movements, and strabismus workup Orbit examination, evaluation of lid abnormalities, and ptosis workup Meticulous slit-lamp examination IOP measurement by Goldmann applanation tonometry Detailed fundus examination Orbital ultrasound: In cases with media opacity due to vitritis, cataract, or corneal opacity, this modality helps diagnose the associated posterior segment pathology. Ultrasound biomicroscopy is used to look for ciliary body changes. [15] Orbital imaging: Orbital computed tomography (CT) scan is used to evaluate the changes in bony orbit.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Evaluation -- Neurology Evaluation
content: Electroencephalogram: For workup of epilepsy cases, to localize the cerebral lesions Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis: CSF examination is usually found normal. The oligoclonal bands and raised IgG index are associated with T2 hyperintense lesions on MRI. [19] Neuro-imaging: CT scan delineates the cranial bony deformity, thinning of diploe, and intracranial calcifications. MRI T1 sequence localizes the patches of cerebral atrophy. MRI T2 sequence pinpoints the hyperintense foci in the subcortical region. MR angiogram demonstrates the extent and location of vascular malformations. Brain spectral photoemission CT (SPECT) scan can detect subclinical CNS lesions in PRS cases. [27]
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Evaluation -- Neurology Evaluation. Electroencephalogram: For workup of epilepsy cases, to localize the cerebral lesions Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis: CSF examination is usually found normal. The oligoclonal bands and raised IgG index are associated with T2 hyperintense lesions on MRI. [19] Neuro-imaging: CT scan delineates the cranial bony deformity, thinning of diploe, and intracranial calcifications. MRI T1 sequence localizes the patches of cerebral atrophy. MRI T2 sequence pinpoints the hyperintense foci in the subcortical region. MR angiogram demonstrates the extent and location of vascular malformations. Brain spectral photoemission CT (SPECT) scan can detect subclinical CNS lesions in PRS cases. [27]

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Evaluation -- Rheumatology Evaluation
content: Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA): The most commonly associated serology finding in 25 to 52% of cases. [28] Rheumatoid factor: Elevated titers in localized scleroderma and LSCS cases. [29] Other serology tests: C-reactive protein, HLA-B27 typing, extractable nuclear antigen, Anti-Scl-70, Anti-cardiolipin, and Anti-dsDNA antibodies are of limited value
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Evaluation -- Rheumatology Evaluation. Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA): The most commonly associated serology finding in 25 to 52% of cases. [28] Rheumatoid factor: Elevated titers in localized scleroderma and LSCS cases. [29] Other serology tests: C-reactive protein, HLA-B27 typing, extractable nuclear antigen, Anti-Scl-70, Anti-cardiolipin, and Anti-dsDNA antibodies are of limited value

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Evaluation -- Dental Evaluation
content: To  monitor progressive deformity of the jaw bones and teeth abnormalities by serial orthopantomograms and photographs.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Evaluation -- Dental Evaluation. To  monitor progressive deformity of the jaw bones and teeth abnormalities by serial orthopantomograms and photographs.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Evaluation -- Dermatology Evaluation
content: Skin biopsy is not performed routinely. However, the histopathological findings help differentiate PRS from LSCS.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Evaluation -- Dermatology Evaluation. Skin biopsy is not performed routinely. However, the histopathological findings help differentiate PRS from LSCS.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management
content: The goals of management are: To halt the active disease progression and induce remission Treatment of acute exacerbations like seizures and uveitis Cosmetic rehabilitation after complete remission
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management. The goals of management are: To halt the active disease progression and induce remission Treatment of acute exacerbations like seizures and uveitis Cosmetic rehabilitation after complete remission

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Medical Management
content: The standard management is systemic immunosuppression. Methotrexate (MTX) - The preferred agent. The dose is 0.3 to 1 milligram/kilogram/week (mg/kg/wk). MTX is administered in oral or parenteral form. Therapy is continued for 12 to 24 months to prevent relapses. Corticosteroids - MTX is combined with oral prednisolone or intravenous methylprednisolone (IVMP). [30] For two months, oral prednisolone is given at a 1 mg/kg/day dose, followed by tapering doses in the third month. IVMP is administered as pulse therapy at 1000 mg/day for three days every month, for six months. Other agents - Mycophenolate mofetil, cyclophosphamide, hydroxychloroquine, and cyclosporine are employed for resistant cases. Psoralen and ultraviolet A (PUVA) - variable efficacy in halting the disease activity. [31]
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Medical Management. The standard management is systemic immunosuppression. Methotrexate (MTX) - The preferred agent. The dose is 0.3 to 1 milligram/kilogram/week (mg/kg/wk). MTX is administered in oral or parenteral form. Therapy is continued for 12 to 24 months to prevent relapses. Corticosteroids - MTX is combined with oral prednisolone or intravenous methylprednisolone (IVMP). [30] For two months, oral prednisolone is given at a 1 mg/kg/day dose, followed by tapering doses in the third month. IVMP is administered as pulse therapy at 1000 mg/day for three days every month, for six months. Other agents - Mycophenolate mofetil, cyclophosphamide, hydroxychloroquine, and cyclosporine are employed for resistant cases. Psoralen and ultraviolet A (PUVA) - variable efficacy in halting the disease activity. [31]

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Ophthalmic Management
content: Acute uveitis: Topical cycloplegics, topical and systemic steroids are the mainstay treatment. Acute trabeculitis is treated with topical antiglaucoma medications. Relapses are common and aggressive management is the norm.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Ophthalmic Management. Acute uveitis: Topical cycloplegics, topical and systemic steroids are the mainstay treatment. Acute trabeculitis is treated with topical antiglaucoma medications. Relapses are common and aggressive management is the norm.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Ophthalmic Management
content: Keratitis: Lid tapping and profuse topical lubrication are advised for exposure keratopathy. Early diagnosis and treatment of super-added infective keratitis is a must.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Ophthalmic Management. Keratitis: Lid tapping and profuse topical lubrication are advised for exposure keratopathy. Early diagnosis and treatment of super-added infective keratitis is a must.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Ophthalmic Management
content: Corneal opacity: An optical penetrating keratoplasty offers a good visual outcome for severely opacified corneas due to exposure keratopathy, infective keratitis, and primary endothelial failure.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Ophthalmic Management. Corneal opacity: An optical penetrating keratoplasty offers a good visual outcome for severely opacified corneas due to exposure keratopathy, infective keratitis, and primary endothelial failure.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Ophthalmic Management
content: Scleral melt: Scleral patch graft is the preferred management option.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Ophthalmic Management. Scleral melt: Scleral patch graft is the preferred management option.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Ophthalmic Management
content: Glaucoma: Antiglaucoma medications can control the IOP in early cases. The severe cases with inadequate control on topical medications require trabeculectomy surgery.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Ophthalmic Management. Glaucoma: Antiglaucoma medications can control the IOP in early cases. The severe cases with inadequate control on topical medications require trabeculectomy surgery.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Ophthalmic Management
content: Restrictive strabismus: The small-angle deviations are corrected by the prism glasses. The large-angle strabismus cases need definitive surgical correction.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Ophthalmic Management. Restrictive strabismus: The small-angle deviations are corrected by the prism glasses. The large-angle strabismus cases need definitive surgical correction.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Ophthalmic Management
content: Retinal vasculitis: The active disease shows vascular lesions in the mid-peripheral retina and mild vitritis. Topical and systemic immunosuppression is the primary treatment. The advanced disease shows neovascularization, vitreous hemorrhage (VH), or tractional retinal detachment (TRD). The visible non-perfused retina is lasered in cases with posterior segment neovascularization. Vitreoretinal surgery with intravitreal injection of anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (anti-VEGF) is needed for cases of non-resolving VH and TRD.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Ophthalmic Management. Retinal vasculitis: The active disease shows vascular lesions in the mid-peripheral retina and mild vitritis. Topical and systemic immunosuppression is the primary treatment. The advanced disease shows neovascularization, vitreous hemorrhage (VH), or tractional retinal detachment (TRD). The visible non-perfused retina is lasered in cases with posterior segment neovascularization. Vitreoretinal surgery with intravitreal injection of anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (anti-VEGF) is needed for cases of non-resolving VH and TRD.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Neurological Management
content: Seizures: The anti-epileptic drugs are titrated as per response for long-term management. Neuropsychiatric disorders: An expert psychiatrist consultation is essential.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Neurological Management. Seizures: The anti-epileptic drugs are titrated as per response for long-term management. Neuropsychiatric disorders: An expert psychiatrist consultation is essential.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Rehabilitation Strategies
content: Cosmetic rehabilitation is attempted after at least one to two years of halt in the progression of the disease. [32] The commonly employed management options are:
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Rehabilitation Strategies. Cosmetic rehabilitation is attempted after at least one to two years of halt in the progression of the disease. [32] The commonly employed management options are:

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Oculoplastic Management
content: Enophthalmos: Intra-orbital injection of fillers like silicone gel, hyaluronate derivates, or autologous fat graft with adipose-derived stem cells has good cosmetic results.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Oculoplastic Management. Enophthalmos: Intra-orbital injection of fillers like silicone gel, hyaluronate derivates, or autologous fat graft with adipose-derived stem cells has good cosmetic results.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Oculoplastic Management
content: Ptosis: Primary correction of the enophthalmos often provides satisfactory cosmesis. Frontalis sling surgery is reserved for severe cases.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Oculoplastic Management. Ptosis: Primary correction of the enophthalmos often provides satisfactory cosmesis. Frontalis sling surgery is reserved for severe cases.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Oculoplastic Management
content: Eyelid retraction: Surgically treated with levator recession or levator lengthening with relaxing myotomy technique.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Oculoplastic Management. Eyelid retraction: Surgically treated with levator recession or levator lengthening with relaxing myotomy technique.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Oculoplastic Management
content: Lagophthalmos: Persistent lagophthalmos requires surgical correction with permanent lateral tarsorrhaphy.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Oculoplastic Management. Lagophthalmos: Persistent lagophthalmos requires surgical correction with permanent lateral tarsorrhaphy.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Oculoplastic Management
content: Drooping of eyebrow: Browpexy or Z-plasty are good treatment options
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Oculoplastic Management. Drooping of eyebrow: Browpexy or Z-plasty are good treatment options

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Oculoplastic Management
content: Atrophic/Phthisis bulbi: A painless involutional globe with adequately formed conjunctival fornices requires a primary trial of the prosthetic shell. The painful phthisical eye may require enucleation surgery with a silicone implant.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Oculoplastic Management. Atrophic/Phthisis bulbi: A painless involutional globe with adequately formed conjunctival fornices requires a primary trial of the prosthetic shell. The painful phthisical eye may require enucleation surgery with a silicone implant.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Oculoplastic Management
content: Contracted socket: The mucous membrane and fat grafting are needed for a total surgical socket reconstruction in severe cases with forniceal shelving. A healthy socket is then given a trial of the prosthetic shell.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Oculoplastic Management. Contracted socket: The mucous membrane and fat grafting are needed for a total surgical socket reconstruction in severe cases with forniceal shelving. A healthy socket is then given a trial of the prosthetic shell.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Plastic Surgery Management
content: Synthetic tissue fillers: Minimally invasive modality to correct facial asymmetry. The commonly employed fillers are silicone gel, polyethylene, hydroxyapatite, and poly L-lactate. [33] These have excellent results in mild to moderate disease. Autologous fat grafting: The Coleman technique has acceptable cosmetic outcomes for most cases. [34] Skeletal reconstruction: Bone paste cranioplasty, bone implants, bone/cartilage grafts, and orthognathic surgery have variable success rates. Free soft tissue transplantation: Extensively used for large volume reconstruction. Commonly used flap sites are greater omentum, lateral thigh, parascapular muscles, latissimus dorsi muscle, and dorsal thoracic adipofascial flap. This procedure provides satisfactory cosmetic outcomes.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Treatment / Management -- Plastic Surgery Management. Synthetic tissue fillers: Minimally invasive modality to correct facial asymmetry. The commonly employed fillers are silicone gel, polyethylene, hydroxyapatite, and poly L-lactate. [33] These have excellent results in mild to moderate disease. Autologous fat grafting: The Coleman technique has acceptable cosmetic outcomes for most cases. [34] Skeletal reconstruction: Bone paste cranioplasty, bone implants, bone/cartilage grafts, and orthognathic surgery have variable success rates. Free soft tissue transplantation: Extensively used for large volume reconstruction. Commonly used flap sites are greater omentum, lateral thigh, parascapular muscles, latissimus dorsi muscle, and dorsal thoracic adipofascial flap. This procedure provides satisfactory cosmetic outcomes.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis
content: The closest differential diagnosis for PRS include the following:
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis. The closest differential diagnosis for PRS include the following:

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis
content: Rassmussen encephalitis (RE): It presents with unilateral cerebral involvement and intractable seizures. Focal neurological deficits and subsequent atrophy mimic the presentation of PRS. The histopathological findings of lymphocytic vasculitis in both RE and PRS may complicate the diagnosis. PRS may be associated in cases of RE, developing progressive hemifacial atrophy. [35]
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis. Rassmussen encephalitis (RE): It presents with unilateral cerebral involvement and intractable seizures. Focal neurological deficits and subsequent atrophy mimic the presentation of PRS. The histopathological findings of lymphocytic vasculitis in both RE and PRS may complicate the diagnosis. PRS may be associated in cases of RE, developing progressive hemifacial atrophy. [35]

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis
content: Barraquer-Simons syndrome: It is an acquired progressive lipodystrophy disorder affecting the face, neck, thorax, abdomen, and rarely the extremities. Central nervous system involvement is suggested by epilepsy and bilateral cerebral atrophy. A gradual symmetric bilateral loss of subcutaneous fat tissue with renal involvement helps differentiate this syndrome from PRS. [36]
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis. Barraquer-Simons syndrome: It is an acquired progressive lipodystrophy disorder affecting the face, neck, thorax, abdomen, and rarely the extremities. Central nervous system involvement is suggested by epilepsy and bilateral cerebral atrophy. A gradual symmetric bilateral loss of subcutaneous fat tissue with renal involvement helps differentiate this syndrome from PRS. [36]

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis
content: Hemifacial hypertrophy: This condition shows an asymmetric enlargement of half of the face and head instead of hemiatrophy. [37] It is an important clinical differential for asymmetric facial deformity.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis. Hemifacial hypertrophy: This condition shows an asymmetric enlargement of half of the face and head instead of hemiatrophy. [37] It is an important clinical differential for asymmetric facial deformity.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis
content: Hemifacial fat necrosis: The causes range from bulbar poliomyelitis, connective tissue diseases to trauma. The absence of muscular or osseous involvement helps differentiate these causes from PRS. [38]
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis. Hemifacial fat necrosis: The causes range from bulbar poliomyelitis, connective tissue diseases to trauma. The absence of muscular or osseous involvement helps differentiate these causes from PRS. [38]

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis
content: Congenital deformities: Conditions like congenital hemiatrophy or torticollis may mimic facial asymmetry caused by PRS. A careful history of onset helps differentiate these entities.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Differential Diagnosis. Congenital deformities: Conditions like congenital hemiatrophy or torticollis may mimic facial asymmetry caused by PRS. A careful history of onset helps differentiate these entities.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Staging
content: The currently used classification system for PRS cases is: [39] Mild: Skin and/or subcutaneous fat atrophy over a single division of the trigeminal nerve Moderate: Skin and/or fat atrophy involving two branches of the trigeminal territory Severe: Atrophy spread over all three divisions of the trigeminal nerve or any bony atrophy
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Staging. The currently used classification system for PRS cases is: [39] Mild: Skin and/or subcutaneous fat atrophy over a single division of the trigeminal nerve Moderate: Skin and/or fat atrophy involving two branches of the trigeminal territory Severe: Atrophy spread over all three divisions of the trigeminal nerve or any bony atrophy

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Prognosis
content: The disease reaches the burn-out phase within 2-20 years of active disease activity. The facial asymmetry is often significant with gross disfigurement. The ocular manifestations ranging from uveitis to keratitis to retinal pathologies require active management. Repeated attacks of uveitis or retinal vasculitis can lead to secondary glaucoma, with variable visual prognosis. The neurological manifestations are often well controlled and cause minimal disability.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Prognosis. The disease reaches the burn-out phase within 2-20 years of active disease activity. The facial asymmetry is often significant with gross disfigurement. The ocular manifestations ranging from uveitis to keratitis to retinal pathologies require active management. Repeated attacks of uveitis or retinal vasculitis can lead to secondary glaucoma, with variable visual prognosis. The neurological manifestations are often well controlled and cause minimal disability.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Complications -- Ophthalmic Complications
content: Corneal opacity Glaucoma Restrictive strabismus Retinal detachment Loss of vision Phthisis bulbi or atrophic bulbi Contracted socket
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Complications -- Ophthalmic Complications. Corneal opacity Glaucoma Restrictive strabismus Retinal detachment Loss of vision Phthisis bulbi or atrophic bulbi Contracted socket

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Complications -- Neurological Complications
content: Recurrent seizure attacks and status epilepticus Subarachnoid hemorrhage from rupture of the cerebral aneurysms [9] Spontaneous carotid-jugular fistula and carotid dissection, due to cerebral vascular malformations Cerebral infarction from focal stenosis of the cerebral vasculature
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Complications -- Neurological Complications. Recurrent seizure attacks and status epilepticus Subarachnoid hemorrhage from rupture of the cerebral aneurysms [9] Spontaneous carotid-jugular fistula and carotid dissection, due to cerebral vascular malformations Cerebral infarction from focal stenosis of the cerebral vasculature

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Deterrence and Patient Education
content: The onset of PRS is heralded by the appearance of pigmentary lesions on the neck and face, followed by progressive facial asymmetry and neurological and ocular features. Early medical-care-seeking behavior among the general population can aid in early diagnosis. Adequate compliance to treatment can halt facial disfigurement. The current advances help in early and desirable cosmetic outcomes for the patients.
contents: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Deterrence and Patient Education. The onset of PRS is heralded by the appearance of pigmentary lesions on the neck and face, followed by progressive facial asymmetry and neurological and ocular features. Early medical-care-seeking behavior among the general population can aid in early diagnosis. Adequate compliance to treatment can halt facial disfigurement. The current advances help in early and desirable cosmetic outcomes for the patients.

title: Parry-Romberg Syndrome -- Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes
content: The cases of PRS may be present in the clinics of ophthalmology, neurology, or dermatology departments. These cases need a multi-specialty evaluation and management. Therefore, a coordinated team approach involving the neurologist, ophthalmologist, rheumatologist, dermatologist, radiologist, plastic surgeon, pharmacist, and other concerned specialties as per the patient's need, is essential.

These cases need a multi-specialty evaluation and management. Therefore, a coordinated team approach involving the neurologist, ophthalmologist, rheumatologist, dermatologist, radiologist, plastic surgeon, pharmacist, and other concerned specialties as per the patient's need, is essential.
